comments.commentBody: It might be a red bellied woodpecker.  They're notorious 'drummers' and it's a territorial and mating announcement.  You should be grateful that it's a drainpipe and not the roof of a treasured roadster.  They have been known to get fixated on those too.  When I hammer fence stakes I have often attracted local pileated woodpeckers who might be thinking I've found something tasty.  They hit the rotten branches of certain trees they've bee keeping an ear out for, get the current crop of grubs and fly off.
Can I buy your dog?  Only kidding.  But he sounds like a treasure.

Skunks are notorious eggers. Secondary predators, they are pretty tough on birds and small ground animals. They also often get the wrong idea when people leave their cat foot outside, and become domesticated. Nothing quite like having an old Victorian Porch with a family of skunks living beneath it to find out which of your friends have absolutely no sense of smell.

Advice to those who would trap and move them, be sure to enclose the Have a Heart trap in plastic tarp with a large garbage bag in place to close and wrap it or you will have a memorable experience trying to move the skunk.

At work, us workers in our cubicles worked out a signal for when one of us spotted the boss on his way. The alarm traveled from cubicle to cubicle in seconds.

All animals develop survival skills against predators.

Had to try it when I read your comment, Dan. My cat too:)

My nearly 18 lb Maine Coone awoke from a sound sleep to see what was the matter and where was it?!!

She is trained to stay in our yard and only gets to go out with human supervision a as she is quite the accomplished little hunter though birds are out of her league and she seems to know it. They seem to know it too and to realize that our chaperone routine is for everyone's protection. I only hear alert calls for the many raptors in the area. Lots of hawks and owls.

Yes, cats can be trained. If they want something badly enough they will negotiate terms to get it. You can't coerce cats, but you can negotiate with them and come up with a workable solution that protects the local wildlife without declawing, a barbaric practice.

We have an amazing tree canopy where I live, especially considering I am in town. When my husband first arrived here from Tehran he thought it was a city built in a jungle. The trees have unfortunately thinned a bit since then as builders today don't respect old growth trees when they "develop" land in the area, for instance the much hated new walmart going up down the street. We already had plenty of merchants and could easily reach a walmart if we wanted one. Which we don't.

I have observed (heard) this first hand at my home in rural Maine. One day I was siting with my cat next to me. All of a sudden many different birds started making a strange call, My cat perked up and repeated the exact call a number of times. I know she is aware of large birds of prey when she goes outside since eagle and falcons are  active in this  area.  She studies the sky and trees when she goes out. Her repetition 0f the bird warnings of what I took for her passing on the warning, was confirmed a day later when I found a large falcon like bird who had crashed through a window in my garage and had tried to crash through another to exit but had died in its attempt.

Yes, but if you use technical terminology (in an obscure dialect, no less) a large fraction of the audience won't understand (i.e. will lack the appropriate conditioning history) and the meaning of the article will be lost (the readers will fail to condition).

These cognitive-to-behavioural translations may have a place in some scientific literature but they often provide only an illusion of clarity.

Noam Chomsky discussed this in 1967 in his review of the work of B.F. Skinner:

"The preceding discussion covers all the major notions that Skinner introduces in his descriptive system. My purpose in discussing the concepts one by one was to show that in each case, if we take his terms in their literal meaning, the description covers almost no aspect of verbal behavior, and if we take them metaphorically, the description offers no improvement over various traditional formulations." http://chomsky.info/articles/1967----.htm

The lack of basic scientific understanding (or perhaps just wishful anthropomorphic thinking) displayed here amazes me. There is absolutely no requirement for a bird to "understand" the "meaning" of another bird species' (or even squirrel!) warning calls in order for it to confer an evolutionary advantage. An identical behavioural effect can be elicited through simple Pavlovian conditioning: pairing of a sensory input (a specific alarm call) and an aversive stimulus (predator).

If automobile noise from a nearby road is disturbing to birds, imagine how much worse leaf blowers are.  I've been in the forest and heard what I thought was planes taking off - it turned out to be a nearby leaf blower.  This is the scourge of the suburbs.
I did the same three times today when a sharp-shinned hawk was after robin nestlings in a tree outside my window. I know the hawk has to eat but hearing the cries of the robins was too much to bear.

Ethics: words = deeds. Simple. Say what you do, do what you say.

Morals: ethics + ever-changing social, spiritual, religious, political, familial, economic (etc.) variables based on age, gender, education, culture, creed and class. What may be considered moral in one culture might very well be totally immoral in another.

Equality, much like pregnancy is - or isn't A woman is or isn't pregnant.

People say they support equality. Do they? We'll see just how ethical those words are on Friday!

How come that all the top management was missing at the time of FIA raid? Maybe someone from agencies tipped them. How come  this fraudulent operation was going on so long and neither our( Pakistani) media nor our agencies could notice it till Walsh of NYT published an investigative report? Were  our agencies silent  and happy with their own cuts and media sleeping? Now all the agencies have sprung in to action including Senate Committee.
This is why I love the NY Times.  Great job here!

Lincoln did a marvelous job of convincing Americans that the Civil War was a war to keep the nation, not to end slavery while he was able to convince the British it was a war to end slavery.  He did have excellent help in this by his ambassador to Britain Charles Francis Adams.

The realm of foreign affairs is yet another of the many areas in which Abraham Lincoln proved to be a more effective leader, than Jefferson Davis. Lincoln wisely, and timely, took the moral high ground on the international stage, with regard to slavery. He smoothed over the Trent affair with the Brits, maintained at least a semi-effective naval blockade of the South, and sent a message to the French regarding their intervention in Mexico.

I cannot think of a single foreign policy success of the Davis administration. They bet on the foreign need for slave-produced cotton, and they overestimated that need, and underestimated the moral attitudes in other countries, toward its means of production.

I understand "never again should the strong be allowed to massacre the weak".
You seem to understand "never again should anyone interfere with the right of Jewish people to do whatever they want."
Palestinians never had a chance. Not one. It's always that way when colonizers from Europe occupy the indigenous people.

When Jordan controlled the West Bank and Jerusalem and Egypt controlled Gaza until 1967 did the Palestinians demand a state? Did the world demand a state? Why not? If the Palestinians were a people with rights for a homeland why didn't they? Why only when Israel won the 1967 war did that happen?

Charlie gets it exactly right. I noted below a similar comment before reading this better one.

Every time this comes up, the comments against Israel all seem to be based on the last 10 years of history, like Israel is some huge powerful nation with no refugees, no lost property, etc. No. Israel accepted a tiny proportion of what they were meant to have. (Britain intended the Jordan river to divide the Israeli side from the Arab side.) They were immediately attacked and each time gave back some of their gains. Israel didn't start the war in which they acquired Jerusalem and the West Bank; but frankly at this point, giving it back should be under their own terms.

Israeli teams don't ever win big and certainly come no where near winning the World Cup or European championships. Palestinian teams are hardly even a speck on the soccer map.

If anybody thinks that this type of thing brings a deal closer, then they are incorrect. All it does is convince Israelis who might have agreed to some type of concessions in the "real world", that the world is against them and they will dig in their heals.

FIFA, the Pope and whatever, will not bring peace and make a deal. Only Israelis and Palestinians will. That requires sitting at the table.

The Palestinians don't like their Israeli counterparts; too bad, this is what there is now. They had other chances and they blew them.

If they prefer to make their stand on a soccer field, they might win, but not a state.

South Africa practiced a racist policy of institutional segregation. Israel practices a security policy of containment of their declared enemies, whom insist on destroying them and refuse to recognize their right to exist. In the past Israel has handed back the Sinai and the Gaza strip and forced established settlements to be abandoned and destroyed in an attempt to trade land for peace.

I do not see how anyone can even compare the two acts as being close to the same policy. This is nothing more then another example of the PLA/PLO using the world forum to spread misinformation about this conflict. Two bad President Abbas doesn't have the backing or political nerve to negotiate a two state solution.
Aren't there rules for the occupying country that the US and Allies followed when occupying Germany and Japan that Israel is flagrantly violating?
FIFA singled out apartheid South Africa.  That was discriminatory. Perhaps more countries need to be suspended from FIFA.

Israel used the so-called peace talks as pretexts to steal more West Bank land and build settlements on them.  The so-called peace agreements Israel was willing to accept were unjust and unfair to Palestinians.  The U.S. was never a fair broker.

The cause of the confusion in the next to last paragraph is that Krugman simply will not discuss Obama and continually is saying or implying that he lhas a great policy. Then he attacks the policy indirectly. Half the time he attacks Europe, he is really attacking Obama.

Or take the next post on TTP. Obama is incredibly treating it as one of the greatest potential achievements of his second term, if not the greatest achievement. If that is true, it is a pathetic second term even if you like TTP, But Obama is emotional about it. His attack on Warren for opposing it is as passionate as anything he has said. So does Krugman even mention it is an Obama program. No. Instead he attacks William Daley.

Some time in coming weeks, Krugman will say Obama has a great second term. If it passes, does that not imply his great achievement.

If one wants to influence an Administration, you simply cannot give it a pass on everything. It then has no reason to worry about you and adjust policy. Krugman is never going to change. But any younger reader who wants to participate in the debate and has such a great platform has to learn the lesson.
I wish you a very long and happy life, RM. The Pope has just referred to Mr. Abbas as an angel of peace.
I see you have not heard.  The present Pope is named Francis.  And although I assume you are not of the Catholic faith, you appear to believe in the Doctrine of Infallibility.

@ Yes RM so would I but since I am 83 and you are only 70 the odds are much better for you. However, even though I cite a once somewhat optimistic T. E. Lawrence in my comment, I fear there will be some other ending that we cannot view as a resolution, and that neither you nor I nor the other Seven Pillars of Wisdom (NYT Verifieds) can imagine.

Larry

When you lose the support of the Pope, you have obviously gone too far.

I am almost 70 years old. This problem has remained unresolved almost my entire lifetime. I would like to see it resolved before I die.

Nothing strange about it. American Superconductor didn't realize its codes controlling its wind turbine were stolen until it found exactly the same codes from its former customer. Even if companies know about the theft, sometimes they may see their current relationships with certain customers more important. The cost of doing business, if you like! Then, back in the last century, it was rumored that Boeing actually gave its Chinese partners some technologies so it could get the foot in the door.

But when a prized company like Nortel went belly up in part because of industrial espionage, every country needs to draw the line how far is too far, especially when your competitor is no longer simply a copycat but might leapfrog you soon

In the article neither the university they studied at nor the 2 USA companies they worked for complained about trading secret  being stolen. The thieves themselves applied patent. What a strange case!

@JF: "... its removal also denies the chance for other people to observe and call out that comment's ignorance & hyperbole."

Thanks, JF. I agree. The Times should be enabling rebuttal instead of enforcing censorship.
Let's not confuse Americans of Chinese descent with students born and raised abroad who come here to study.

Well endowed individuals with the U.S.A. made such theft possible
through the blindness of economic greed. One only speaks on what
has made such theft possible.
